title: Sydney Onayemi
text:
Abayomi Sydney Onayemi (3 November 1937 – 1 May 2016), also known as Big Brother Sydney, was a Nigerian-born Swedish <a href="disc%20jockey">disc jockey</a>.
His other name "Abayomi" means "he brings me joy and happiness" in the <a href="Yoruba%20Language">Yoruba</a> language. Onayemi came to <a href="Sweden">Sweden</a> in 1962 to study <a href="finance">finance</a> at the prestigious <a href="Stockholm%20School%20of%20Economics">Stockholm School of Economics</a>. After two years he had to drop out of school due to lack of money. In order to pay his bills he started working at restaurants, mainly cleaning bathrooms at the Strands Maritime. Eventually he started <a href="deejaying">deejaying</a> <a href="soul%20music">soul</a>, and later <a href="funk">funk</a> and <a href="disco">disco</a>, music that was fairly new to <a href="Sweden">Sweden</a>. He also sang along to the tracks, added maracas and other live percussions. In 1972 he opened his own discothèque "Big Brother".
He opened his fourth discothèque "Confetti" in 1984, a gay discothèque, and also worked as resident <a href="DJ">DJ</a> at various other discothèques throughout the years. In between he also opened the discothèques "Knattedisco" and "1984".
In 2010 he came out of retirement for a onetime event at the "Loveboat 12" club, celebrating the <a href="Disco">Disco</a> era.
Influence.
He was largely credited as introducing the two <a href="Phonograph">turntable</a> style of <a href="deejaying">deejaying</a> from the <a href="United%20States">United States</a> and <a href="Jamaica">Jamaica</a> to <a href="Scandinavia">Scandinavia</a>. He has also been credited for introducing <a href="Sweden">Swedish</a> 1980s <a href="New%20wave%20music">new wave</a> and <a href="synthpop">synthpop</a> acts like <a href="Mauro%20Scocco">Ratata</a>, <a href="Mauro%20Scocco">Mauro Scocco</a> and <a href="Lustans%20Lakejer">Lustans Lakejer</a> to <a href="funk">funk</a> music according to <a href="Lustans%20Lakejer">Lustans Lakejer</a> vocalist <a href="Lustans%20Lakejer">Johan Kinde</a> and nightclub entrepreneur "Joakim Langer".
In a 2012 <a href="radio">radio</a> documentary, <a href="Sveriges%20Radio">Swedish National Radio</a> named him the nation's first superstar <a href="Disc%20Jockey">Disc Jockey</a>.
Personal life.
He retired and lived in the <a href="%C3%96stermalm">Östermalm</a> neighbourhood of <a href="Stockholm">Stockholm</a>.
